message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Toward an Earth-Independent System for EVA Mission Planning: Integrating Physical Models, Domain Knowledge, and Agentic RAG to Provide Explainable LLM-Based Decision Support
Paper Abstract: We propose a unified framework for an Earth‑independent AI system that provides explainable, context‑aware decision support for EVA mission planning by integrating six core components: a fine‑tuned EVA domain LLM, a retrieval‑augmented knowledge base, a short-term memory store, physical simulation models, an agentic orchestration layer, and a multimodal user interface. To ground our design, we analyze the current roles and substitution potential of the Mission Control Center - identifying which procedural and analytical functions can be automated onboard while preserving human oversight for experiential and strategic tasks. Building on this framework, we introduce RASAGE (Retrieval & Simulation Augmented Guidance Agent for Exploration), a proof‑of‑concept toolset that combines Microsoft Phi‑4‑mini‑instruct with a FAISS (Facebook AI Similarity Search)‑powered EVA knowledge base and custom A* path planning and hypogravity metabolic models to generate grounded, traceable EVA plans. We outline a staged validation strategy to evaluate improvements in route efficiency, metabolic prediction accuracy, anomaly response effectiveness, and crew trust under realistic communication delays. Our findings demonstrate the feasibility of replicating key Mission Control functions onboard, enhancing crew autonomy, reducing cognitive load, and improving safety for deep‑space exploration missions.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

I've completed a web search for "Large Language Model." Here's what I found:

## Definition

A large language model (LLM) is a language model trained with self-supervised machine learning on a vast amount of text, designed for natural language processing tasks, especially language generation.

## Key Characteristics

They consist of billions to trillions of parameters and operate as general-purpose sequence models, generating, summarizing, translating, and reasoning over text.(no content)The largest and most capable LLMs are generative pre-trained transformers (GPTs) and provide the core capabilities of modern chatbots.

## Capabilities

LLMs represent a significant new technology in their ability togeneralize across tasks with minimal task-specific supervision, enabling capabilities like conversational agents, code generation, knowledge retrieval, and other applications.

## Architecture

As of 2024, the largest and most capable models are all based on the transformer architecture.

## Recent Developments

Since 2023, many LLMs have been trained to be multimodal, having the ability to also process or generate other types of data, such as images, audio, or 3D meshes.

The search results provide comprehensive information about LLMs, including well-known examples like GPT-3, BERT, and Meta's Llama models.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Knowledge graph"

Links: [{"title":"Knowledge graph - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knowledge_graph"},{"title":"Knowledge Graph (Google) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knowledge_Graph_(Google)"},{"title":"Knowledge graph embedding - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knowledge_graph_embedding"},{"title":"Category:Knowledge graphs - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Knowledge_graphs"},{"title":"Personal knowledge base - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personal_knowledge_graph?oldformat=true"},{"title":"Data Commons - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_Commons"},{"title":"Semantic analysis (knowledge representation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semantic_analysis_(knowledge_representation)"}]

## Knowledge Graph

A knowledge graph is a knowledge base that uses a graph-structured data model or topology to represent and operate on data.(no content)Knowledge graphs are often used to store interlinked descriptions of entities – objects, events, situations or abstract concepts – while also encoding the free-form semantics or relationships underlying these entities.

### History and Development

The term was coined as early as 1972 by the Austrian linguist Edgar W. Schneider, in a discussion of how to build modular instructional systems for courses.(no content)In 2012, Google introduced their Knowledge Graph, building on DBpedia and Freebase among other sources.(no content)The Google Knowledge Graph became a successful complement to string-based search within Google, and its popularity online brought the term into more common use.

### Applications

Knowledge graphs are used by search engines such as Google, Bing, and Yahoo; knowledge engines and question-answering services such as WolframAlpha, Apple's Siri, and Amazon Alexa; and social networks such as LinkedIn and Facebook.

### Key Features

A knowledge graph defines abstract classes and relations of entities in a schema, mainly describes real world entities and their interrelations, organized in a graph, allows for potentially interrelating arbitrary entities with each other, and covers various topical domains.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Multimodal learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multimodal_learning"},{"title":"Multimodal representation learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multimodal_representation_learning"},{"title":"Multimodal pedagogy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multimodal_pedagogy"},{"title":"Foundation model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foundation_models"},{"title":"Computer-supported collaborative learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E-Learning_2.0"},{"title":"Learning styles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Learning_styles"},{"title":"Digital literacy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_literacy"},{"title":"Digital media in education - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_media_in_education"},{"title":"Large language model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Large_language_model"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about multimodal learning:

## Definition and Core Concept

Multimodal learning is a type of deep learning that integrates and processes multiple types of data, referred to as modalities, such as text, audio, images, or video.(no content)This integration allows for a more holistic understanding of complex data, improving model performance in tasks like visual question answering, cross-modal retrieval, text-to-image generation, aesthetic ranking, and image captioning.

## Real-World Motivation

Data usually comes with different modalities which carry different information. For example, it is very common to caption an image to convey the information not presented in the image itself.

##Recent Developments

Large multimodal models, such as Google Gemini and GPT-4o, have become increasingly popular since 2023, enabling increased versatility and a broader understanding of real-world phenomena. Additionally, since 2023, many LLMs have been trained to be multimodal, having the ability to also process or generate other types of data, such as images, audio, or 3D meshes, and are also called large multimodal models (LMMs), or multimodal large language models (MLLMs).

## Applications

Multimodal learning has diverse applications across multiple domains, including cross-modal retrieval, which allows users to search for data across different modalities (e.g., retrieving images based on text descriptions), improving multimedia search engines and content recommendation systems, as well as healthcare diagnostics, where multimodal models integrate medical imaging, genomic data, and patient records to improve diagnostic accuracy and early disease detection, especially in cancer screening.

Links: [{"title":"Multimodal learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multimodal_learning"},{"title":"Multimodal representation learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multimodal_representation_learning"},{"title":"Multimodal pedagogy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multimodal_pedagogy"},{"title":"Foundation model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foundation_models"},{"title":"Computer-supported collaborative learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E-Learning_2.0"},{"title":"Learning styles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Learning_styles"},{"title":"Digital literacy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_literacy"},{"title":"Digital media in education - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_media_in_education"},{"title":"Large language model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Large_language_model"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about multimodal learning:

## Definition and Core Concept

Multimodal learning is a type of deep learning that integrates and processes multiple types of data, referred to as modalities, such as text, audio, images, or video.(no content)This integration allows for a more holistic understanding of complex data, improving model performance in tasks like visual question answering, cross-modal retrieval, text-to-image generation, aesthetic ranking, and image captioning.

## Real-World Motivation

Data usually comes with different modalities which carry different information. For example, it is very common to caption an image to convey the information not presented in the image itself.

##Recent Developments

Large multimodal models, such as Google Gemini and GPT-4o, have become increasingly popular since 2023, enabling increased versatility and a broader understanding of real-world phenomena. Additionally, since 2023, many LLMs have been trained to be multimodal, having the ability to also process or generate other types of data, such as images, audio, or 3D meshes, and are also called large multimodal models (LMMs), or multimodal large language models (MLLMs).

## Applications

Multimodal learning has diverse applications across multiple domains, including cross-modal retrieval, which allows users to search for data across different modalities (e.g., retrieving images based on text descriptions), improving multimedia search engines and content recommendation systems, as well as healthcare diagnostics, where multimodal models integrate medical imaging, genomic data, and patient records to improve diagnostic accuracy and early disease detection, especially in cancer screening.

Web search results for query: "A* search algorithm"

Links: [{"title":"A* search algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A*_search_algorithm"},{"title":"Search algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Search_algorithm"},{"title":"Iterative deepening A* - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iterative_deepening_A*"},{"title":"Best-first search - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Best-first_search"},{"title":"Anytime A* - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anytime_A*"},{"title":"Pathfinding - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pathfinding"},{"title":"SMA* - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SMA*"},{"title":"Category:Search algorithms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Search_algorithms"},{"title":"Binary search - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Binary_search"},{"title":"List of algorithms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_algorithms"}]

Here's what I found about the A* search algorithm:

## Overview

A* (pronounced "A-star") is a graph traversal and pathfinding algorithm that is used in many fields of computer science due to its completeness, optimality, and optimal efficiency.(no content)The algorithm was first published in 1968 by Peter Hart, Nils Nilsson and Bertram Raphael of Stanford Research Institute (now SRI International).

## How It Works

A* can be seen as an extension of Dijkstra's algorithm and achieves better performance by using heuristics to guide its search.(no content)A* search algorithm can be presented by the function of f(n) = g(n) + h(n), where n is the last node on the path, g(n) is the cost of the path from the start node to n, and h(n) is a heuristic thatestimates the cost of the cheapest path from n to the goal.

## Key Characteristics

Compared to Dijkstra's algorithm, the A* algorithm only finds the shortest path from a specified source to a specified goal, and not the shortest-path tree from a specified source to all possible goals.(no content)The A* search algorithm is an example of a best-first search algorithm, and best-first algorithms are often used for path finding in combinatorial search.

## History

A* was created as part of the Shakey project, which had the aim of building a mobile robot that could plan its own actions.

## Variants

Several variations of A* have been developed, including Iterative deepening A* (IDA*), which is a variant of iterative deepening depth-first search that borrows the idea to use a heuristic function to conservatively estimate the remaining cost to get to the goal from the A* search algorithm.

Web search results for query: "Extravehicular activity"

Links: [{"title":"Extravehicular activity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extravehicular_activity"},{"title":"Extravehicular Mobility Unit - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extravehicular_Mobility_Unit"},{"title":"Category:Extravehicular activity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Extravehicular_activity"},{"title":"Feitian space suit - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feitian_space_suit"},{"title":"List of spacewalkers - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_spacewalkers"},{"title":"AERCam Sprint - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AERCam_Sprint"},{"title":"SEATEST II - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SEATEST_II"},{"title":"Dana Weigel - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dana_Weigel"},{"title":"Kathleen Rubins - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kathleen_Rubins"},{"title":"Category:Spacewalkers - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Spacewalkers"}]

## Extravehicular Activity (EVA)

Extravehicular activity (EVA) is any activity done by an astronaut in outer space outside a spacecraft.(no content)In the absence of a breathable Earthlike atmosphere, the astronaut is completely reliant on a space suit for environmental support.

### Types of EVA

EVA includes spacewalks and lunar or planetary surface exploration (commonly known from 1969 to 1972 as moonwalks).(no content)In a stand-up EVA (SEVA), an astronaut stands through an open hatch but does not fully leave the spacecraft.

### History

NASA planners invented the term extravehicular activity (abbreviated with the acronym EVA) in the early 1960s for the Apollo program to land humans on the Moon, because the astronauts would leave the spacecraft to collect lunar material samples and deploy scientific experiments.(no content)On March 18, 1965, Alexei Leonov became the first human to perform a spacewalk, exiting the Voskhod 2 capsule for 12 minutes and 9 seconds.(no content)On July 20, 1969, Neil Armstrong became the first human to perform a moonwalk, outside his lunar lander on Apollo 11 for 2 hours and 31 minutes.

### Current Participation

EVAs have been conducted by the Soviet Union/Russia, the United States, and China; astronauts from Canada, Japan, the United Arab Emirates, and the European Space Agency have also participated in EVAs conducted by those nations.(no content)As of September 2025, the following 12 countries have flown spacewalkers meeting these criteria: United States of America (153), Russia (formerly Soviet Union) (75), China (22), Japan (5), Canada (4), France (4), Germany (4), Italy (2), Switzerland (1), Sweden (1), Great Britain (1) and United Arab Emirates (1).

I've completed the web search for "Mission planning." Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Planning is the process of thinking regarding the activities required to achieve a desired goal. When applied to missions, this concept takes on more specific forms depending on the context.

## Military Mission Planning

The Marine Corps Planning Process is the primary planning process used by the United States Marine Corps at all levels.(no content)This planning process involves six steps: Problem Framing, Course of Action (COA) Development, COA Wargaming, COA Comparison and Decision, Orders Development, and Transition.(no content)A military operation plan is a formal plan for military armed forces, their military organizations and units to conduct operations, as drawn up by commanders within the combat operations process in achieving objectives before or during a conflict.

## Specialized Mission Planning Systems

For specific applications like space missions, EZIE science operations are managed at the Science Operations Center using the SciBox autonomous mission planning system, which automates the generation of flight command sequences, optimizes operations planning, and enforces spacecraft constraints.

In military force deployment, JADE is a U.S. military system used for planning the deployment of military forces in crisis situations, developed to expedite the creation of detailed planning needed to deploy military forces for a military operation.

I've completed the web search for "Mission planning." Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Planning is the process of thinking regarding the activities required to achieve a desired goal. When applied to missions, this concept takes on more specific forms depending on the context.

## Military Mission Planning

The Marine Corps Planning Process is the primary planning process used by the United States Marine Corps at all levels.(no content)This planning process involves six steps: Problem Framing, Course of Action (COA) Development, COA Wargaming, COA Comparison and Decision, Orders Development, and Transition.(no content)A military operation plan is a formal plan for military armed forces, their military organizations and units to conduct operations, as drawn up by commanders within the combat operations process in achieving objectives before or during a conflict.

## Specialized Mission Planning Systems

For specific applications like space missions, EZIE science operations are managed at the Science Operations Center using the SciBox autonomous mission planning system, which automates the generation of flight command sequences, optimizes operations planning, and enforces spacecraft constraints.

In military force deployment, JADE is a U.S. military system used for planning the deployment of military forces in crisis situations, developed to expedite the creation of detailed planning needed to deploy military forces for a military operation.

I've completed the web search for "Space exploration". Here's a summary of the findings:

## Overview

Space exploration is the physical investigation of outer space by uncrewed robotic space probes and through human spaceflight.(no content)The development of large and relatively efficient rockets during the mid-twentieth century allowed physical space exploration to become a reality.

## Key Rationales and Milestones

Common rationales for exploring space include advancing scientific research, national prestige, uniting different nations, ensuring the future survival of humanity, and developing military and strategic advantages against other countries.(no content)The early era of space exploration was driven by a "Space Race" in which the Soviet Union and the United States vied to demonstrate their technological superiority. Notable achievements include the launch of the first human-made object to orbit Earth, the Soviet Union's Sputnik 1, on 4 October 1957, and the first Moon landing by the American Apollo 11 mission on 20 July 1969.

## Current Trends

The 2000s brought advancements in the national space-exploration programs of China, the European Union, Japan, and India. The 2010s saw the rise of the private space industry in earnest with the development of private launch vehicles, space capsules, and satellite manufacturing.(no content)In the 2020s, the two primary global programs gaining traction are Moon-focused: the Chinese-led International Lunar Research Station and the U.S.-led Artemis Program, with its plan to build the Lunar Gateway and the Artemis Base Camp, each with a set of international partners.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Retrieval-augmented generation"

Links: [{"title":"Retrieval-augmented generation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Retrieval-augmented_generation"},{"title":"Prompt engineering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prompt_engineering"},{"title":"Large language model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Large_language_model"},{"title":"Retrievability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Retrievability"},{"title":"Generative artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generative_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Generative engine optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generative_engine_optimization"},{"title":"Talk:You.com - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Draft_talk:You.com"},{"title":"Knowledge extraction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knowledge_extraction"},{"title":"Natural language generation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_language_generation"},{"title":"Geographic information retrieval - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geographic_Information_Retrieval"}]

## Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG)

Retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) enhances large language models (LLMs) by incorporating an information-retrieval mechanism that allows models to access and utilize additional data beyond their original training set.

### How RAG Works

With RAG, LLMs do not respond to user queries until they refer to a specified set of documents that supplement information from the LLM's pre-existing training data. The process generally involves:

1. **Data Retrieval**: RAG pulls relevant text from databases, uploaded documents, or web sources.
2. **Encoding**: The data to be referenced is converted into LLM embeddings, numerical representations in the form of a large vector space, which are then stored in a vector database to allow for document retrieval.
3. **Query Processing**: Given a user query, a document retriever is first called to select the most relevant documents, and the model feeds this relevant retrieved information into the LLM via prompt engineering of the user's original query.

### Benefits

RAG allows LLMs to use domain-specific and/or updated information that is not available in the training data, which helps LLM-based chatbots access internal company data or generate responses based on authoritative sources. Additionally, RAG reduces the need to retrain LLMs with new data, saving on computational and financial costs.

### Advantages for Accuracy

RAG is a way of improving LLM performance by blending the LLM process with a web search or other document look-up process to help LLMs stick to the facts, and this method helps reduce AI hallucinations.

Here's what I found about metabolic rate and energy expenditure:

## Overview

Energy expenditure, often estimated as the total daily energy expenditure (TDEE), is the amount of energy burned by the human body.

## Key Components of Energy Expenditure

Resting metabolic rate generally composes 60 to 75 percent of TDEE.(no content)Basal metabolic rate (BMR) is the rate of energy expenditure per unit time by endothermic animals at rest.(no content)Thermic effect of food is the amount of energy burned digesting food, around 10 percent of TDEE. Additionally, energy burned during physical activity includes the exercise activity thermogenesis (EAT) and non-exercise activity thermogenesis (NEAT).

## Factors Affecting Metabolic Rate

Several factors influence energy expenditure:

- **Body Composition**: Fat free mass is a better predictor of metabolic rate than total weight, and increasing skeletal muscle tissue can increase metabolic rate.

- **Age and Body Size**: In humans, BMR typically declines by 1–2% per decade after age 20, mostly due to loss of fat-free mass.

- **Sex**: Men carry more skeletal muscle tissue on average than women, and other sex differences in organ size account for sex differences in metabolic rate.

## Measurement Methods

Indirect calorimetry is considered the gold-standard method to measure RMR. This involves measuring oxygen consumption and carbon dioxide production to determine energy expenditure.

Resting metabolic rate generally composes 60 to 75 percent of TDEE.(no content)Basal metabolic rate (BMR) is the rate of energy expenditure per unit time by endothermic animals at rest.(no content)Thermic effect of food is the amount of energy burned digesting food, around 10 percent of TDEE. Additionally, energy burned during physical activity includes the exercise activity thermogenesis (EAT) and non-exercise activity thermogenesis (NEAT).

## Factors Affecting Metabolic Rate

Several factors influence energy expenditure:

- **Body Composition**: Fat free mass is a better predictor of metabolic rate than total weight, and increasing skeletal muscle tissue can increase metabolic rate.

- **Age and Body Size**: In humans, BMR typically declines by 1–2% per decade after age 20, mostly due to loss of fat-free mass.

- **Sex**: Men carry more skeletal muscle tissue on average than women, and other sex differences in organ size account for sex differences in metabolic rate.

## Measurement Methods

Indirect calorimetry is considered the gold-standard method to measure RMR. This involves measuring oxygen consumption and carbon dioxide production to determine energy expenditure.

I've completed a web search for "Autonomous agents artificial intelligence." Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Basics

An autonomous agent is an artificial intelligence (AI) system that can perform complex tasks independently.(no content)In artificial intelligence, an intelligent agent is an entity that perceives its environment, takes actions autonomously to achieve goals, and may improve its performance through machine learning or by acquiring knowledge.

## Modern AI Agents (Agentic AI)

In the context of generative artificial intelligence, AI agents (also referred to as compound AI systems or agentic AI) are a class of intelligent agents distinguished by their ability to operate autonomously in complex environments.(no content)Agentic AI tools prioritize decision-making over content creation and do not require human prompts or continuous oversight. They possess several key attributes, including complex goal structures, natural language interfaces, the capacity to act independently of user supervision, and the integration of software tools or planning systems.

## Key Characteristics

Common characteristics include persistence, autonomy (agents have capabilities of task selection, prioritization, goal-directed behavior, and decision-making without human intervention), social ability (agents can engage other components through communication and coordination), and reactivity (agents perceive their environment and react appropriately).

## Applications and Examples

A common application of AI agents is the automation of tasks—for example, booking travel plans based on a user's prompted request. Prominent examples include Devin AI, AutoGPT, and SIMA. Further examples of agents released since 2025 include OpenAI Operator, ChatGPT Deep Research, Manus, Quark, AutoGLM Rumination, and Coze.

Bloomfield - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CASCON_(decision_support_system)"},{"title":"Automated decision support - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_decision_support"},{"title":"Executive information system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Executive_information_system"}]

## Search Results for "Decision Support System"

Here's an overview of decision support systems based on the search results:

### Definition and Purpose
A decision support system (DSS) is an information system that supports business or organizational decision-making activities.(no content)A properly designed DSS is an interactive software-based system intended to help decision makers compile useful information from a combination of raw data, documents, personal knowledge, and/or business models to identify and solve problems.

### Key Characteristics
DSS has many tools that contain different functions such as sophisticated database management capabilities with access to internal and external data, information, and knowledge; powerful modeling functions accessed by a model management system; and powerful, yet simple user interface designs that enable interactive queries, reporting, and graphing functions.

### History
The concept of decision support has evolved mainly from the theoretical studies of organizational decision making done at the Carnegie Institute of Technology during the late 1950s and early 1960s, and the implementation work done in the 1960s. DSS became an area of research of its own in the middle of the 1970s, before gaining in intensity during the 1980s.

### Applications
DSS is used across various domains:
- DSS is extensively used in business and management. Executive dashboard and other business performance software allow faster decision making, identification of negative trends, and better allocation of business resources.
- A clinical decision support system (CDSS) is a form of health information technology that provides clinicians, staff, patients, or other individuals with knowledge and person-specific information to enhance decision-making in clinical workflows.
- A spatial decision support system (SDSS) is an interactive, computer-based system designed to assist in decision making while solving a semi-structured spatial problem.

Links: [{"title":"Real-time path planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real-time_path_planning"},{"title":"Motion planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motion_planning"},{"title":"Any-angle path planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Any-angle_path_planning"},{"title":"D* - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/D*"},{"title":"Rapidly exploring random tree - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rapidly_exploring_random_tree"},{"title":"Wavefront expansion algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wavefront_expansion_algorithm"},{"title":"Probabilistic roadmap - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Probabilistic_roadmap"},{"title":"Vector Field Histogram - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vector_Field_Histogram"},{"title":"Graphical path method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graphical_path_method"},{"title":"Multi-agent pathfinding - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_pathfinding"}]

## Path Planning Algorithm - Search Results

I found comprehensive information about path planning algorithms. Here's an overview:

### Definition
Motion planning, also path planning (also known as the navigation problem or the piano mover's problem) is a computational problem to find a sequence of valid configurations that moves the object from the source to destination.(no content)The term is used in computational geometry, computer animation, robotics and computer games.

### Types of Approaches

**Real-Time Path Planning:**
Real-Time Path Planning is a term used in robotics that consists of motion planning methods that can adapt to real time changes in the environment. This is divided into:
- Global path planning refers to methods that require prior knowledge of the robot's environment.
- Local path planning refers to methods that take in information from the surroundings in order to generate a simulated field where a path can be found. This allows a path to be found in the real-time as well as adapt to dynamic obstacles.

### Common Algorithms

Several major path planning algorithms include:

1. **Probabilistic Roadmap (PRM):** The probabilistic roadmap planner is a motion planning algorithm in robotics, which solves the problem of determining a path between a starting configuration of the robot and a goal configuration while avoiding collisions.

2. **Rapidly Exploring Random Tree (RRT):** A rapidly exploring random tree (RRT) is an algorithm designed to efficiently search nonconvex, high-dimensional spaces by randomly building a space-filling tree. The tree is constructed incrementally from samples drawn randomly from the search space and is inherently biased to grow towards large unsearched areas of the problem.

3. **Vector Field Histogram (VFH):** In robotics, Vector Field Histogram (VFH) is a real time motion planning algorithm proposed by Johann Borenstein and Yoram Koren in 1991.

Self-driving vehicles are a form of mobile robots that utilizes real-time path planning. Oftentimes a vehicle will first use global path planning to decide which roads to take to the target. message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title, relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
